channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Myanmar, a Notable Burmese Family Quietly Equipped a Brutal Military
item.description: A Burmese-Irish family said all the right things, even as it helped Myanmar’s rulers avoid sanctions scrutiny in buying airplanes, defense radar and more.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Senior Gen. Min Aung Hlaing, Myanmar’s military commander in chief, during a parade for the 76th Armed Forces Day in Naypyidaw, the capital, in March.

item.title: How Do Saudis Celebrate Christmas? Quietly, but Less So.
item.description: “Am I in Saudi Arabia?” Once officially banned, Christmas is coming out of hiding in the kingdom, as its ultra-constrictive religious rules are eased.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Iman Al-Dabbagh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Umniah Alzahery and her husband, Mike Bounacklie, putting a Christmas sweater on their dog as they prepared to celebrate Christmas in their home in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Europeans Ponder Living With, Not Defeating, Covid
item.description: On the eve of the biggest holidays in Europe, exhaustion with the pandemic is rising. So is resignation that the virus is endemic.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Casey, Constant Méheut and José Bautista
item.media:description: Lining up outside La Paz Hospital in Madrid for a coronavirus test on Thursday.

item.title: An Afghan Official Laments What Was Lost and Looks to What Lies Ahead
item.description: Ahmad Nader Nadery spent decades working toward a thriving, free Afghanistan. Watching the Taliban undo much of his work, he wonders how to move forward.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ahmad Nader Nadery, a former senior advisor to the president of Afghanistan, in Hoofddorp, the Netherlands, in December.

item.title: Despite Omicron Wave, Britons Are Set on Not Losing Another Christmas
item.description: For Christmas shoppers in central London this week, little seemed to dampen their spirits. But there was an undercurrent that the city was bracing for further coronavirus restrictions.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times

item.title: As Hindu Extremists Call for Killing of Muslims, India’s Leaders Keep Silent
item.description: Right-wing Hindu activists at a conference took an oath to harm Muslims if necessary to make “a Hindu-only nation,” the most blatant example of rising anti-Muslim sentiment across India.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Muslims praying on Friday in Gurugram, India. Hindu nationalists have interrupted prayers there in recent months with battle cries.

item.title: Fire on Crowded Bangladesh Ferry Leaves Dozens Dead
item.description: Officials confirmed 35 deaths, but they said the toll was likely to rise as search and rescue continued.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat
item.media:description: Firefighters and coast guard personnel working Friday at the scene of the ferry disaster near the town of Jhalakathi, Bangladesh.

item.title: Thousands of Christmas Flights Canceled as Omicron Spreads
item.description: New York’s governor shortened the isolation period for essential workers who are mostly asymptomatic. South Africa, with cases falling, ended quarantines and stopped contact tracing.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: A plane at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport in Arlington, Virginia on Wednesday.

item.title: Park Geun-hye, Ex-Leader of South Korea, to Be Pardoned
item.description: The government said it would release Ms. Park on Dec. 31 in the interest of national “reconciliation.”
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: President Park Geun-hye became the first South Korean leader to be removed from office through parliamentary impeachment.

item.title: Japan Approves Major Hike in Military Spending, With Taiwan in Mind
item.description: The budget increase, the biggest in decades, comes as officials warn that tensions over Taiwan could pull Japan into a conflict between the United States and China.
item.dc:creator: Makiko Inoue and Ben Dooley
item.media:description: A live-fire military exercise in Gotemba, Japan, in May.

item.title: Putin Mixes Positive Note With Threats, Keeping West on Edge
item.description: At a traditional year-end news conference, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said a potential meeting with the U.S. was a positive sign, but he also demanded a quick response to his security concerns.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Andrew E. Kramer and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia held his traditional year-end news conference on Thursday.

item.title: Canada and Indigenous People Settle Over Drinking Water
item.description: A court-approved settlement will compensate Indigenous people for the decades that many have lived with dirty water, and will also fund the clean up.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Tara Walton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Buckhorn Lake on Curve Lake First Nation land earlier this month. The reserve was pivotal in bringing forward the civil suit for access to clean drinking water.

item.title: Bros' Restaurant in Italy: Chef Finds Fame After Epic Takedown
item.description: Panned by a prominent blogger, the Italian restaurant Bros’ and its celebrity chef became a global target for critics of pretentious cuisine. There was a good side for him.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Serving the final dish of a 13-course tasting menu that left a blogger complaining,“there was nothing even close to an actual meal served.”

item.title: South Africa Ends Quarantining and Contact Tracing
item.description: The new regulations follow data showing that while the Omicron variant is highly transmissible, it has not caused high rates of severe disease in South Africa.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A volunteer at a drive-through Covid vaccination site in Pretoria, South Africa, this month.

item.title: Travel Between U.S. and Southern Africa Will Resume, White House Says
item.description: Biden will end the ban at midnight on Dec. 31, reversing restrictions imposed last month. South Africa criticized the ban as discriminatory.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: A plane at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport in Arlington, Virginia on Wednesday.

item.title: Portraits of Our Times
item.description: We look at the Lives They Lived.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: From left: Shayan Asgharnia/AUGUST, John Springer Collection/Getty Images, Tierney & Killingsworth/Photofest
item.media:description: From left, Michael K. Williams, Cloris Leachman and Larry King.

item.title: A Quieter Christmas for Queen Elizabeth II as Covid Persists
item.description: The 95-year-old monarch is spending the holiday at Windsor Castle instead of Sandringham, her English country estate.
item.dc:creator: Aina J. Khan
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II is having a quieter Christmas for the second year in a row.

item.title: Suga of BTS Tests Positive for Covid
item.description: The K-pop star Suga discovered that he was infected after returning to South Korea from the United States.
item.dc:creator: Yonette Joseph
item.media:description: Suga of the K-pop group BTS, in New York in 2020.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Israel’s decision on a fourth Covid-19 vaccine dose.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A woman receives a booster shot of her Covid-19 vaccination at an assisted living facility in Netanya, Israel.

item.title: Second Deadly Migrant Boat Crash Off Greece This Week
item.description: Ninety people were left stranded after Thursday’s accident. The crash came in a week that also saw scores of migrants die in wrecks off the coast of Libya.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Greek Coast Guard vessel on patrol in July in the Aegean Sea.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Israel Weighs Fourth Dose
item.description: Scientists debate its necessity, but some say there isn’t time to wait.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: A man took a selfie while receiving a third dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine in Ramat Gan, Israel, in August.

item.title: New York’s virus surge has leaders balancing health and political risks.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos and Katie Glueck
item.media:description: Democratic leaders like Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York are trying to balance managing another huge health challenge with reassuring the public that they are not interested in revisiting lockdowns.

item.title: U.S. Considers Warning Ukraine of a Russian Invasion in Real-Time
item.description: U.S. officials say intelligence sharing is essential to the Ukrainian government’s survival, even as they try to avoid escalating the situation.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier fires a Javelin missile during a military exercise. The United States has been supplying Ukraine with the anti-tank guided missiles since 2018.

item.title: Lapid Says Israel Will Support Iran Nuclear Pact, if It’s ‘a Good Deal.’
item.description: The Israeli foreign minister said “we have no problem with a deal,” but perhaps because he thinks the prospects of an agreement are remote.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Patrick Kingsley
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yair Lapid, Israel’s foreign minister, speaking in Washington in October.

item.title: Israel May Give 4th Dose of Covid Shot, Despite Experts' Doubts
item.description: Some scientists warn that too many shots might actually harm the body’s ability to fight the Covid-19 virus. But Israeli experts say there isn’t time to wait.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Older Israelis received a third Covid-19 vaccine in Tel Aviv in August.

item.title: Lab tests suggest that using AstraZeneca’s vaccine as a booster may protect against Omicron, the company says.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: A man receiving the AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine as a booster dose at a hospital in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, in August.

item.title: Cecilia McDowall to Debut New Christmas Carol
item.description: Each year, the choir of King’s College, Cambridge, commissions an original song for its Christmas service, giving the composer an audience of around 100 million people.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall

item.title: U.S. Effort to Combat Forced Labor Targets Corporate China Ties
item.description: The Biden administration is expected to face scrutiny as it decides how to enforce a new ban on products made with forced labor in the Xinjiang region of China.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson, Catie Edmondson and Edward Wong
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: Uyghur workers at a factory in the Xinjiang region of China in 2019. A wide range of products and raw materials flow from the region, where accusations of forced labor proliferate.

item.title: National Guard members take on new roles at nursing homes.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.media:credit: Tim Gruber for The New York Times
item.media:description: Minnesota National Guard Members checked on a resident at North Ridge Health and Rehab in New Hope, Minn., on Dec. 16.

item.title: Older Americans are displaying a mix of worry and resolve heading into the holidays.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman and Julie Bosman
item.media:credit: Greg Lovett/The Palm Beach Post, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Americans who are 65 or older have the highest vaccination rates but are also the most at risk from Covid-19.

item.title: Israel weighs giving approval for 4th vaccine doses.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Israel is considering a fourth Covid-19 shot as it faces rising rates of cases due to the omicron variant.

item.title: What does it mean to be ‘fully vaccinated’ against Covid-19?
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat
item.media:credit: Frederic J. Brown/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A sign offering free Covid-19 vaccinations and booster shots at a pop-up clinic in the international arrivals area of Los Angeles International Airport on Dec. 22.

item.title: Hong Kong Removes 'Pillar of Shame' Statue Amid Crackdown
item.description: The decision to take down the “Pillar of Shame,” an enduring symbol of the territory’s pro-democracy movement, was another sign of Beijing’s crackdown.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements of China
item.media:description: Workers removing part of the “Pillar of Shame” statue at the University of Hong Kong on Thursday.

item.title: Putin says he won’t pursue fines or prosecute unvaccinated people in Russia.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Andrew E. Kramer and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: “We need to relate to people with respect,” President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said of Covid-19 vaccinations at his annual news conference in Moscow on Thursday.

item.title: Covid’s Risk to Older Adults
item.description: Ready to give up on the pandemic? Spare a moment to think about older people.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Janice Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Passing out home test kits in New York City yesterday.

item.title: More European countries, seeing record case spikes, embrace pediatric vaccines and tighter restrictions.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah, Gaia Pianigiani, Constant Méheut and Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: France began vaccinating children aged 5-11 on Wednesday.

item.title: As the virus surges again, U.S. colleges worry about a mental health crisis.
item.dc:creator: Anemona Hartocollis
item.media:description: Students on the Stanford University campus in California in March 2019.

item.title: When will the 500 million free tests that Biden promised be available?
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:description: Abbott Laboratories makes the BinaxNOW Covid-19 Antigen Self Test. It destroyed thousands of tests — now in great demand — earlier in the year.

item.title: Fury in China After Li Tiantian, an Outspoken Teacher, Disappears
item.description: Supporters of Li Tiantian believe that local officials may have sent her to a psychiatric hospital, a longstanding way of stifling and discrediting dissent.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: China tells Winter Olympic spectators to clap, not cheer, for athletes, and Xi’an, a major city, locks down.
item.description: As the Omicron variant spreads elsewhere, China is taking elaborate precautions to prevent the virus from reaching participants when the Games start in February.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: Olympic workers on Tuesday near the National Ski Jumping Center in Zhangjiakou, China. During the Games, waiters, cleaners and other support staff will not be allowed to leave venues to visit their families.

item.title: Omicron-Driven Pushes for Boosters Could Prolong Pandemic, W.H.O. Says
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah
item.media:description: Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, the W.H.O.’s director-general, warned on Wednesday that booster programs in highly vaccinated nations could take resources away from largely unvaccinated ones.

item.title: How to Catch a Polar Bear
item.description: First, spot the bear.
item.dc:creator: Anna Filipova and Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Anna Filipova for The New York Times

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Encouraging data on Omicron.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Jane Barlow/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A vaccination line in Edinburgh this week.

item.title: ‘Koala Massacre’: Australia Files Hundreds of Animal Cruelty Charges
item.description: A property owner and two companies in Australia were charged after a land-clearing operation left dozens of the marsupials dead, injured or starving.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: A koala that was brought to a rehabilitation center after its habitat was destroyed in the Australian state of Victoria. Dozens of others died.

item.title: Omicron Infections Seem to Be Milder, Three Research Teams Report
item.description: The data offer a rare bit of good news. Still, hospitalizations are likely to increase simply because the variant is so contagious.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer and Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: John Taggart for The New York Times
item.media:description: Covid-19 testing from a van in Manhattan on Tuesday. Experts warn that Americans should take rapid tests before holiday events and should gather outside, open windows or find other ways to improve ventilation.

item.title: Three Dead and Many Missing as Migrant Boat Sinks Near Greece
item.description: The sinking came just weeks after 27 people drowned trying to cross the English Channel, another stark reminder of the lethal risks facing asylum seekers.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Aegean Sea, where the Greece Coast Guard rescued 12 survivors from a smuggler boat in distress.

item.title: Studies Find Omicron May Be Less Severe Than Delta
item.description: U.K. studies found fewer hospitalizations compared to Delta.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Victoria Jones/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Medical staff tended to patients in a Covid ward at King's College Hospital, in London on Tuesday.

item.title: California Requires Health Workers to Get Boosters by Feb. 1
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom said more than half of the sequenced cases in the state have been identified as the Omicron variant, but the real number is probably higher.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:description: A coronavirus test being administered in the international terminal at Los Angeles International Airport on Tuesday.

item.title: CityMD Temporarily Shuts 19 Locations Amid Urgent Testing Demands
item.description: The closures began on Wednesday, and CityMD has not said how long they will last.
item.dc:creator: Precious Fondren
item.category: City Practice Group of New York (CityMD)
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Waiting in line for a Covid-19 test at a CityMD clinic in Washington Heights.

item.title: What would it cost to end the pandemic?
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden takes questions from reporters after delivering remarks on Covid-19 in the State Dining Room of the White House in Washington on Tuesday.

item.title: Reimposed travel restrictions spoil another Christmas season in the Holy Land.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: The Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem, built on the traditional site of Jesus’ birth, will see few Christian pilgrims this year because of pandemic travel restrictions imposed by Israel.

item.title: As Humanitarian Disaster Looms, U.S. Opens Door for More Afghanistan Aid
item.description: The Treasury Department and the United Nations offered new protection for aid from sanctions meant to pressure the Taliban.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sacks of flour from a World Food Program convoy were unloaded in Afghanistan in October. The Treasury Department will make it easier for international organizations and the U.S. government to provide relief to Afghans while maintaining economic pressure on the Taliban.

item.title: Covid Spoils Another Christmas in the Holy Land
item.description: Israel’s strict border controls have largely barred foreign tourists from entry, but the traditional Jerusalem Santa is managing to bring some local cheer.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Issa Kassissieh, the traditional Santa Claus of the Holy Land, entertaining a few visitors in his workshop this week.

item.title: Turkey issues emergency-use authorization for its domestically produced vaccine.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Esra Hacioglu/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A health worker in Ankara, Turkey, prepares to administer a booster dose of the country’s Turkovac vaccine to a volunteer in a clinical trial.

item.title: Americans are tired, and Omicron is just beginning.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Ariana Drehsler for The New York Times
item.media:description: A diner in San Diego on Monday.

item.title: Much maligned during the pandemic, caroling is back. Outside London pubs, that is.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Carol singers outside the Mayflower pub in London last week. Live singing has been among the most demonized of cultural activities since the pandemic, since it has been linked to superspreader events.

item.title: ‘The Daily’: A Covid testing crisis, again.
item.media:description: Boxes of BinaxNow home Covid-19 tests made by Abbott Laboratories on sale in November at a CVS store in Lakewood, Wash.

item.title: Decoding Joe Manchin
item.description: The senator’s history suggested he could vote for Build Back Better. Why didn’t he?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joe Manchin at a Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources hearing.

item.title: Holiday traveling and Omicron: Here are some strategies for staying safe.
item.dc:creator: Heather Murphy
item.media:description: Experts advise getting tested as close to the day of a gathering as possible.
